{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14920,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carex debilis, commonly known as the weak sedge, prefers consistently moist soil conditions but can tolerate occasional dry periods once established. It is important not to let the soil dry out completely. Supplemental watering may be necessary during prolonged periods of drought or in particularly dry regions. Ensure good drainage to prevent root rot, as soggy soil can be detrimental. Watering once or twice a week, depending on the local climate and soil moisture levels, should suffice. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and maintain even soil humidity."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"For optimal growth, Carex debilis requires partial to full shade, mimicking its natural habitat in woodlands and shaded areas. It can tolerate some morning sun but thrives best when sheltered from intense afternoon sun, which can scorch its leaves. If grown in sunnier locations, ensure that the soil remains consistently moist to prevent stress. In cooler regions, it may tolerate more sun exposure. Carex debilis is an excellent choice for shaded garden beds, under trees, or as a groundcover in woodland gardens, where it will receive indirect sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex debilis involves trimming back dead or damaged leaves to maintain its appearance and encourage healthy growth. This can be done in early spring before new growth begins. Use sharp, clean scissors or pruning shears to cut back the foliage to a few inches above the ground. Additionally, if the plant becomes too large or loses its shape, it can be divided and replanted. This should be done every few years in the fall or early spring to rejuvenate the plant. Regular pruning helps to prevent the spread of disease and encourages a dense, lush growth habit."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"white-edge sedge","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["white-edge sedge"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Root rot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Carex debilis"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14324,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Oenothera macrocarpa, commonly known as the bigfruit evening primrose, is relatively drought-tolerant once established. It prefers well-drained soil and should be watered moderately until established. After establishment, water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's essential to let the soil dry between waterings. During periods of high heat, you may need to water more frequently, but during cooler months, reduce watering to prevent waterlogging, allowing the plant to thrive in its natural dry environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oenothera macrocarpa thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and bloom production. Planting it in a sunny location will ensure the most vibrant display of its large yellow flowers. While it can tolerate partial shade, flowering may be reduced, and the plant might become lanky. It's best to avoid placing it in areas with dense shade, as insufficient sunlight can weaken the plant and lead to poor flowering. Ensure it receives full sun for the best performance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Oenothera macrocarpa involves removing spent flowers and stems to encourage a tidy appearance and promote more blooms through the growing season. After the blooming period, it is beneficial to cut back the plant to about half its height to encourage healthy growth and prevent legginess. Regular deadheading can also stimulate further blooms. In late fall or early spring, a more extensive prune can be carried out to remove any dead or damaged growth, preparing the plant for robust growth in the following season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"bigfruit evening primrose","description":"Oenothera macrocarpa, the bigfruit evening primrose, Ozark sundrop or Missouri evening primrose, is a species of flowering plant in the evening primrose family Onagraceae, native to Mexico and the south-central United States, where it is found in calcareous prairies and limestone outcrops.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["bigfruit evening primrose"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Oenothera macrocarpa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14128,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Helianthus giganteus, commonly known as the giant sunflower, prefers consistent moisture but not soggy conditions. For optimal growth, ensure the soil remains moist, especially during hot, dry periods. Water the plant deeply once or twice a week, depending on rainfall and temperature, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and reduce the frequency of watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Helianthus giganteus thrives in full sun conditions, requiring a minimum of 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal flowering and growth. Ideally, choose a planting location that receives unimpeded sunlight throughout the day to ensure the best performance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is beneficial for Helianthus giganteus to encourage bushier growth and remove any dead or diseased foliage. In late fall or early spring, cut back the plant to about 6 inches above the ground to promote new growth. Throughout the growing season, deadhead spent blooms regularly to prolong flowering and improve the plant’s appearance. Thin out crowded stems to improve air circulation and reduce the risk of diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"giant sunflower","description":"Helianthus giganteus (giant sunflower or tall sunflower), is a species of Helianthus native to the eastern United States and eastern and central Canada, from Newfoundland west to Alberta south to Minnesota, Mississippi, and South Carolina.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["giant sunflower"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Helianthus giganteus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14624,"attracts":["Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Sabal palmetto, or cabbage palm, is quite drought-tolerant once established. Initially, young palms should be watered regularly to help establish a strong root system, perhaps two to three times a week depending on rainfall. Mature palms require less frequent watering, around once a week, or less if there is significant rain. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. Ensure the soil is well-draining, and let the top inch of soil dry out between waterings. Adjust the frequency based on climate and soil conditions to ensure optimal growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sabal palmetto thrives in full sunlight but can tolerate partial shade as well. Ideally, the palm should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and health. In areas with intense sunlight during the hottest part of the day, some partial shade can help prevent leaf scorch, especially for younger plants. In its native habitat, it grows in sunny coastal regions and uplands, indicating its preference for bright conditions. Plant in a location where it won’t be overshadowed by taller trees or structures."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for the Sabal palmetto involves removing dead or dying fronds to help maintain a tidy appearance and promote overall plant health. Do not over-prune, as this can stress the palm. Only cut fronds that are completely brown and no longer provide any photosynthetic benefit to the tree. It's best to prune these fronds in late spring or early summer. Avoid cutting the healthy, green fronds, and be careful not to damage the trunk while pruning, as this can lead to diseases or pests infiltrating the tree."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"cabbage palmetto","description":"Sabal palmetto, also known as cabbage-palm, palmetto, cabbage palmetto, blue palmetto, Carolina palmetto, common palmetto, swamp cabbage and sabal palm, is one of 15 species of palmetto palm. It is native to the southernmost lowlands and coastal areas of the southern United States, as well as Cuba, the Turks & Caicos Islands, and The Bahamas.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southeastern United States","Bahamas","Cuba"],"other_name":["cabbage palmetto"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spots","Ganoderma butt rot","Leaf blight"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Sabal palmetto"],"soil":["Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14821,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pyrostegia venusta, commonly known as flame vine, requires regular watering to establish a healthy root system, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. Water the plant thoroughly, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During hot or dry periods, the frequency of watering should increase to prevent the soil from drying completely. However, be cautious not to overwater as this can lead to root rot. In fall and winter, reduce watering as the plant enters its dormant phase. Ensure the plant is in well-drained soil to prevent standing water around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pyrostegia venusta thrives in full sun to produce its best show of vibrant orange flowers. Provide it with at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate some light shade, flowering may be reduced, and growth may become spindly. In warmer climates, providing afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive heat. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south-facing window to ensure it receives sufficient sunlight. Ensuring the plant gets adequate sunlight will help it maintain its dense foliage and vigorous flowering throughout its blooming season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Pyrostegia venusta regularly to maintain its shape and encourage vigorous flowering. The best time to prune this vine is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove all dead, damaged, or weak stems to promote healthy plant growth. If the plant becomes too large, reduce its size by cutting back overgrown shoots. Training and guiding the vine along support structures can also be achieved during pruning. This not only keeps the plant tidy but also helps in improving air circulation around the foliage, reducing the risk of fungal diseases. Regular pruning encourages dense foliage and abundant blooms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Flame vine","description":"Pyrostegia venusta, also commonly known as flamevine or orange trumpetvine, is a plant species of the genus Pyrostegia of the family Bignoniaceae originally endemic to Brazil, but nowadays a well-known garden species.","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Brazil","Paraguay","Argentina"],"other_name":["Flame vine"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Pyrostegia venusta"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15120,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rosa carolina, commonly known as the Carolina rose, requires regular watering, especially in its first year of growth to establish a strong root system. It's essential to keep the soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. Deep watering once a week is recommended, letting the top inch of soil dry out between waterings. During dry spells or high heat in the growing season, you may need to increase the frequency slightly. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering, though care should be taken to avoid water accumulation, which can lead to root rot issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rosa carolina thrives in full sun conditions, preferring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. Sufficient sunlight is crucial for healthy flowering and growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, inadequate sunlight may lead to reduced flowering and poorer health overall. When choosing a planting spot, ensure it's relatively open and free from excessive shade cast by buildings or other trees. If growing conditions are hotter, mild afternoon shade can help protect the plant from extreme heat but aim to maximize morning sunlight exposure to encourage optimal growth and blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carolina roses involves selective cutting to promote healthy growth and enhance blooming. The best time for pruning is late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead or damaged wood first, then thin out any overcrowded stems to improve air circulation. Cut the canes back by about one-third to rejuvenate the plant and encourage fuller growth. After initial blooming, light 'deadheading'—removing spent flowers—can stimulate more blooms and keep the plant tidy. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and reduce the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Carolina rose","description":"Rosa carolina, commonly known as the Carolina rose, pasture rose, or low rose, is a shrub in the rose family native to eastern North America, where it can be found in nearly all US states and Canadian provinces east of the Great Plains.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Carolina rose"],"pest_susceptibility":["Black spot","Powdery mildew","Rust","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Rosa carolina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15815,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Allium textile, commonly known as prairie onion, is a drought-tolerant plant that thrives in well-drained soil. Watering should be minimal; it is best to let the soil dry out between waterings. During its growing season, you can water it once every two to three weeks, depending on rainfall and humidity levels. Over-watering can lead to bulb rot, so it's important to ensure the soil is not constantly wet. In dormancy, reduce watering significantly or cease it altogether, as the plant does not require as much moisture during this period."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Allium textile thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight a day to flourish. It is well-suited to open, sunny locations that mimic its natural prairie habitat. If planted in partial shade, the plant may not bloom as profusely and can become leggy as it stretches towards sunlight. Situating this plant in a spot with adequate sun exposure will ensure robust growth and vibrant blooms. However, in hotter climates or during heat waves, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Allium textile is generally minimal. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, will prevent the plant from self-seeding and encourages better flowering the following year. This can be done by snipping off the flower stalks at their base close to the leaf area as they start to wilt and dry out. It's also good practice to remove any dead or yellowing leaves during the growing season to maintain plant health and appearance. In the fall, after the leaves have died back naturally, they can be cleaned away to prepare the plant for winter."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Textile onion","description":"Allium textile (prairie onion or textile onion) is a common species of wild onion found in the central part of North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Textile onion"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Allium textile"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14723,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lasallia papulosa, being a type of lichen, does not require conventional watering like typical houseplants. In its natural habitat, it relies on rain, fog, and dew for moisture. If you’re cultivating or studying it in a controlled environment, lightly misting with water occasionally can simulate its natural moisture intake. Avoid over-watering as lichens are sensitive to waterlogged conditions which can cause decay. It thrives in habitats where it can dry out between moisture events, so ensuring it does not remain constantly wet is crucial for its health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lasallia papulosa typically thrives in regions with moderate to high levels of sunlight, often found on exposed rock surfaces where they get ample light. In a cultivation setting, providing them with indirect sunlight or partial shade is ideal, as direct, intense sunlight for prolonged periods might lead to desiccation. If outdoors, ensure they are located in an area with a natural light cycle, while indoors, consider positioning them near a window with filtered light or under a light source that simulates natural conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lasallia papulosa, like other lichens, is generally not necessary as they grow slowly and maintain their structure fairly well. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14523,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Juniperus deppeana, commonly known as alligator juniper, requires minimal watering once established. It is drought-tolerant and should not be overwatered, as it prefers dry conditions. Initially, water the plant regularly during its first growing season to help establish a deep, extensive root system. Once established, it typically needs water only during prolonged dry spells or drought conditions. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other health issues. Ensure the soil drains well and consider using mulch to retain moisture without over-saturating the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Juniperus deppeana thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. It can tolerate partial shade, but full sun promotes denser foliage and optimal growth. When planting this juniper, choose a location where it will receive ample sunlight throughout the day. Insufficient sunlight can lead to poor growth and sparse foliage. If growing indoors or in less sunny climates, consider supplementing with artificial light to meet the plant's sunlight requirements. Ensure it is placed in a well-lit area to maintain its health and vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Juniperus deppeana should be done carefully and sparingly, as it does not require heavy pruning. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or diseased branches to encourage healthy growth and improve airflow through the plant. Lightly trim back any overgrown branches to maintain the desired shape and size. Avoid cutting into old wood, as junipers do not typically regenerate from old wood. Maintain clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent the spread of disease and to make precise cuts."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"alligator juniper","description":"Juniperus deppeana (alligator juniper or checkerbark juniper; Native American names include táscate and tláscal) is a small to medium-sized tree reaching 10–15 m (rarely to 25 m) tall. It is native to central and northern Mexico (from Oaxaca northward) and the southwestern United States (Arizona, New Mexico, western Texas). It grows at moderate altitudes of 750–2,700 meters (2,460–8,860 ft) on dry soils.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["alligator juniper"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Juniperus deppeana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Morning sunlight is preferable, as the intensity is lower, reducing the risk of leaves scorching during the hottest part of the day. In particularly hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf burn. If growing indoors, place the plant near a south- or west-facing window to ensure it gets ample light, and consider supplemental lighting during darker months."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pelargonium graveolens helps maintain its shape and encourages bushier growth. It’s best to prune in early spring before new growth starts, by cutting back any leggy or overgrown stems to around two-thirds of their length. Regular deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can also promote further blooming. During the growing season, light trimming can be done to remove any dead or yellowing leaves, enhancing airflow and preventing diseases. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to avoid damaging the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rose-scented Geranium","description":"Pelargonium graveolens is an uncommon Pelargonium species native to the Cape Provinces and the Northern Provinces of South Africa, Zimbabwe and Mozambique. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15518,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Prunus armeniaca, commonly known as the apricot tree, requires consistent but moderate watering, especially during its growth and fruiting seasons. It thrives in well-drained soil and should not be left in standing water, which can lead to root rot. Water the plant deeply once or twice a week, depending on the climate and the drainage of the soil. In hotter and drier climates, the tree may need more frequent watering, but ensure the soil dries out between waterings. During the fall and winter months, watering can be reduced as the tree enters a period of dormancy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Prunus armeniaca thrives best in full sun, needing at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day to produce healthy fruit. Plant it in a location where it can receive ample sunlight throughout the day. Sufficient sunlight not only promotes good fruit development but also helps with the overall health of the tree, reducing susceptibility to disease and encouraging strong growth. Avoid planting in shaded areas or where taller structures could block the sunlight. If the growing area is prone to extreme heat, some afternoon shade could be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Prunus armeniaca is essential for encouraging healthy growth and fruit production. It should be done in late winter or early spring before the tree starts to bud. Begin by removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. Thin out excess growth in the center of the tree to allow light and air to penetrate, which helps prevent fungal diseases. Prune away any crossing branches to maintain open shape. Additionally, prune back the tips of vigorous shoots to encourage branch formation. Regular pruning helps maintain the tree’s shape and promotes better fruit yield."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"apricot","description":"Prunus armeniaca (\"Armenian plum\"), the most commonly cultivated apricot species, also called ansu apricot, Siberian apricot, Tibetan apricot, is a species of Prunus, classified with the plum in the subgenus Prunus. The native range is somewhat uncertain due to its extensive prehistoric cultivation, though almost certainly somewhere in Asia. It is extensively cultivated in many countries and has escaped into the wild in many places.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Yellow-Orange\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Central Asia"],"other_name":["apricot"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Borers","Brown rot","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Cutting","Grafting Propagation","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Prunus armeniaca"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14822,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hyacinthus orientalis, commonly known as the hyacinth, requires careful watering to ensure healthy growth. During its growing period in spring, water the plant thoroughly but allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent bulb rot. Once the leaves start to die back in late spring, reduce watering; the plant enters dormancy and excess moisture can damage the bulb. Ensure the soil is well-draining and avoid water-logging, especially if the hyacinth is grown in a container. In areas with heavy rains, additional drainage enhancements may be necessary to keep the bulbs dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hyacinths thrive in full sun to partial shade, requiring about 6 hours of sunlight daily for optimal growth. In cooler climates, full sun exposure is ideal as it promotes vibrant blooms. However, in warmer regions, some afternoon shade can prevent the flowers from prematurely wilting due to excessive heat. If growing indoors, place hyacinths in a bright, sunny window ensuring they receive adequate light. Observe the plants; if they appear to be leaning or stretching towards the light, it may indicate insufficient sunlight, necessitating a relocation to a brighter spot."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning hyacinths primarily involves deadheading spent flowers. As blooms fade, cut the flower stalks down to the base to prevent seed formation, which diverts energy away from bulb growth. Allow the foliage to die back naturally, as they continue to photosynthesize and replenish the bulb for next season's growth. Typically, foliage will turn yellow in late spring to early summer, at which point it can be gently removed or cut back. Avoid removing green foliage to ensure the bulb stores enough energy. Dead or damaged leaves should be promptly removed to maintain plant health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hyacinth","description":"Hyacinthus orientalis (common hyacinth, garden hyacinth or Dutch hyacinth), is a herbaceous perennial flowering plant, native to southwestern Asia, southern and central Turkey, northwestern Syria, Lebanon and northern Israel. It was introduced to Europe in the 16th century. It is widely cultivated everywhere in the temperate world for its strongly fragrant flowers which appear exceptionally early in the season, and frequently forced to flower at Christmas time.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Eastern Mediterranean"],"other_name":["Hyacinth"],"pest_susceptibility":["Bulb rot","Gray mold","Narcissus bulb fly"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb offsets"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Hyacinthus orientalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In areas with extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from leaf scorch. Insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. This plant responds well to shaping and can be pruned to maintain a desired size or form, especially when grown as a hedge or screening plant. Make clean cuts just above a bud or branch junction to encourage healthy new growth. Avoid heavy pruning during peak growing seasons to prevent stress and potential disease infestation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Brush Box","description":"Lophostemon confertus (syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14626,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tortula muralis, commonly known as wall screw-moss, typically requires minimal watering as it is adapted to dry, rocky environments. It's essential to allow the moss to dry between watering to mimic its natural conditions. When growing indoors, maintaining a slightly humid environment can help, and using rainwater is often preferable due to its low mineral content, which mimics the moss's natural habitat."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tortula muralis prefers bright, indirect sunlight. In its natural habitat, it often grows on walls and rocks exposed to varying light conditions, so direct sunlight for extended periods should be avoided as it can dry out the moss. Placing it in a location where it receives filtered light or can enjoy some morning sun while being protected during the harsher afternoon hours is ideal. If you're growing it indoors, a north or east-facing window can provide the right balance of light, promoting healthy photosynthesis without scorching the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tortula muralis is not usually necessary, as mosses generally maintain their shape and size naturally. However, you can occasionally tidy up the plant by removing any dead or discolored parts using a pair of fine scissors. This can encourage a healthier and more vigorous growth. Pruning can also be utilized to encourage a bushier growth habit by selectively cutting back long stems to a healthy bud. Ensure the soil has good drainage to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During the hotter months, you might need to water more frequently. However, allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings to avoid overwatering. A layer of mulch can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering needed."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Verbena urticifolia thrives in full sun to partial shade. For maximum flowering potential and optimal growth, it is best to provide it with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect the plant from excessive heat. If planted in more shaded areas, the plant may have fewer flowers and a more leggy appearance, so balance between sun and shade is key. Ensure it receives enough light for vigorous blooming without causing heat stress or wilting during high temperatures."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Verbena urticifolia involves removing dead or spent flowers to encourage new blooms and prevent the plant from becoming too leggy. This process, known as deadheading, should be done regularly throughout the growing season. If the plant becomes too tall or begins to sprawl, you can also trim back up to one-third of the growth to encourage a bushier appearance. At the end of the growing season, in late fall or early spring, cut back the plant to about 6-8 inches to prepare it for the next growth cycle. Pruning helps maintain a tidy and healthy plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"white vervain","description":"Verbena urticifolia, known as nettle-leaved vervain or white vervain, is a herbaceous plant in the vervain family (Verbenaceae). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16008,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Allium oleraceum, commonly known as field garlic, prefers moderate watering. It's important to allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. During the active growing season in spring and summer, water the plant more frequently, ensuring the soil remains consistently moist but not soggy. Reduce watering significantly in the fall and winter when the plant is dormant. Be attentive to the weather and adjust your watering schedule accordingly, as rain can help keep the soil naturally moist without the need for additional watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Allium oleraceum thrives in full sun to light shade, benefiting from at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. This ensures optimal growth and flowering. However, if you live in an extremely hot or arid region, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from scorching. In partial shade, the plant may still grow but might not bloom as profusely. Well-drained soil and good air circulation are also essential in sunny spots to prevent fungal issues. Adjust the planting location accordingly if the plant shows signs of too much or too little light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Allium oleraceum involves removing dead or yellowing leaves to maintain plant health and aesthetics. This should be done as needed throughout the growing season, typically in late spring and summer. After the flowering period, it's beneficial to remove spent flower stalks at the base to prevent the plant from putting energy into seed production unless you want it to self-seed. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to prevent disease spread, and avoid cutting the foliage back prematurely, as it's necessary for storing energy for the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"field garlic","description":"Allium oleraceum (field garlic) is a Eurasian species of wild onion. It is a bulbous perennial that grows wild in dry places, reaching 30 centimetres (12 in) in height. Prune the plant during the late winter while it is still dormant. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased wood to open up the canopy and improve air circulation, which helps to prevent disease. Train the grapevines on a trellis for support and structure. Also, cut back lateral shoots to encourage the main vine's growth and productivity. Regular pruning helps in maintaining shape and stimulates vigorous new growth, which is essential for good fruit development in the subsequent season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"frost grape","description":"Vitis vulpina (with common names frost grape, winter grape, fox grape, and wild grape.) is a North American species of herbaceous perennial vines in the grape family. Regular pruning helps encourage a strong structure and prolific blooming seasonally."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Texas Ebony","description":"Ebenopsis ebano is a species of flowering plant in the pea family, Fabaceae, that is native to the coastal plain of southern Texas in the United States and eastern Mexico. Adjust the frequency based on rainfall, temperature, and light levels, ensuring the plant is neither too dry nor too soggy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant prefers partial to full shade, making it well-suited for woodland gardens and areas with dappled sunlight or indirect light. It can still survive in areas with some direct light as long as it is not exposed to harsh afternoon sun, which can scorch the leaves and cause stress to the plant. If growing Hackelia virginiana in a pot, move it to an area with sufficient shade during the hottest part of the day, ensuring it receives about two to four hours of sunlight either in the morning or late afternoon."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Hackelia virginiana doesn't typically require extensive pruning. However, removing dead or damaged leaves and stems can promote better air circulation and reduce the risk of disease. If the plant becomes too large or unruly, trim back any overgrown sections to maintain its size and shape. Late winter to early spring is the best time for more significant pruning efforts, allowing for healthy new growth as the plant enters the growing season. Regularly inspect the plant for signs of damage or disease to address issues promptly."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"virginia stickseed","description":"Hackelia virginiana, a biennial plant, is commonly known as beggar's lice, sticktight or stickseed. Ensure the soil never dries out; however, avoid waterlogged conditions that could cause root rot. A practical way to maintain moisture is by placing the pot in a tray with about an inch of water, allowing the plant to absorb water as needed. Additionally, remove any flower stalks after the blooming period to direct more energy to the growth of new pitchers. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16009,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Allowissadula holosericea, commonly known as Velvet-leaf, prefers moderate watering. During its active growing season in the spring and summer, the soil should be kept consistently moist but not waterlogged. It's best to water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Reduce watering during the fall and winter when the plant's growth slows down, allowing the top inch or two of soil to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to prevent water accumulation at the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Allowissadula holosericea thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, provide the plant with at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. A location with southern or western exposure is ideal to ensure it receives enough light. In extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent the leaves from scorching. However, too much shade can result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. If growing indoors, place the plant near a bright window where it can receive similar levels of daylight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Allowissadula holosericea should be done primarily to maintain its shape and remove any damaged or diseased branches. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before the plant begins its active growth period. Start by removing any dead or damaged branches, cutting them back to the base of the plant. Lightly trim any excessively long or unruly branches to maintain a rounded, compact shape. Pruning also encourages new growth and flowering, so avoid heavy pruning during the growing season, as this can reduce the number of blooms the plant produces."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"velvet-leaf mallow","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southwestern United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["velvet-leaf mallow"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Allowissadula holosericea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14825,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Solidago simplex, commonly known as Mountain Goldenrod, prefers consistent moisture in the soil, especially during its growing period. However, it is also quite tolerant of drought once established. For optimal health, water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the top inch or so of soil to dry out in between watering. Be cautious not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. In very dry seasons or climates, more frequent watering might be necessary, but ensure that the soil has good drainage to prevent waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solidago simplex thrives best when exposed to full sun, where it receives at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In these conditions, the plant will produce the most vibrant blooms. It can also tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, which may help protect it from intense afternoon sun and prevent foliage scorch. However, too much shade can result in leggy growth and reduced blooming. When planting, choose a location that provides ample sunlight and avoids overshadowing by larger plants or structures."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solidago simplex is not strictly necessary but can be beneficial for plant health and aesthetics. In late winter or early spring, before new growth appears, remove any dead or damaged stems to encourage fresh growth. Deadheading, or removing spent flower heads, can extend the blooming period and prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively if not desired. Additionally, cutting back the plant by about one-third after flowering can promote bushier growth and help maintain a tidy appearance in the garden."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Sticky Goldenrod","description":"Solidago simplex, the Mt. Albert goldenrod or sticky goldenrod, is a North American plant species in the genus Solidago of the sunflower family. It is widespread across much of Canada, parts of the United States, and northeastern Mexico.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Sticky Goldenrod"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Solidago simplex"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14924,"attracts":["Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carex pensylvanica, commonly known as Pennsylvania sedge, is a grass-like plant that typically requires minimal watering. It prefers moderately moist to dry conditions and is adapted to survive in drought-prone environments once established. Watering should be done deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. In particularly dry periods or regions, providing some supplemental water can help maintain its vigor. However, overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot, especially in poorly draining soils."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carex pensylvanica thrives in partially shaded to fully shaded environments, although it can tolerate full sun if the soil remains consistently moist. Ideally, it should receive dappled sunlight or morning sun with afternoon shade for optimal growth. In full sun exposure, especially in hot climates, the sedge may require more frequent watering to prevent desiccation. In heavily shaded areas under trees or larger shrubs, it competes well and forms a dense ground cover, making it ideal for such settings. It is highly adaptable to various light conditions, enhancing its versatility in garden design."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex pensylvanica is not strictly necessary, but it can benefit from a light trim to rejuvenate and maintain a tidy appearance. In late winter or early spring, any brown or dead foliage can be sheared down to the ground to make way for fresh new growth. This can also help prevent the accrual of thatch. If you prefer a neat appearance year-round, you can also trim back seedheads and any wayward stems as necessary. Be cautious to avoid cutting any emerging foliage to prevent damage to the new growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Pennsylvania sedge","description":"Carex pensylvanica is a species of flowering plant in the sedge family commonly called Pennsylvania sedge (sometimes shortened to Penn sedge). Other common names include early sedge, common oak sedge, and yellow sedge.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Pennsylvania sedge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Carex pensylvanica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Adjust lighting as necessary to meet seasonal changes."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is typically minimal for Platanthera orbiculata. Remove any dead or yellowing leaves to maintain plant health and prevent potential disease spread. This should be done carefully to avoid damaging the plant’s base. After flowering, spent flower stalks can be cut back to encourage more robust growth in the following season. It's best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems to promote healthy plants. During the warmer months, this plant may require watering once a week or more, particularly if it is grown in a container. However, in the winter, watering should be reduced as the plant's growth typically slows down. Ensure the top inch of soil is dry before watering and always allow any excess water to drain away to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cordyline fruticosa thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. While it can tolerate low-light conditions, its vibrant leaf colors will be enhanced with more light. Avoid exposing it to direct afternoon sunlight, especially in hotter climates, as this can scorch the leaves. If grown indoors, placing the plant near an east-facing window or a north-facing window is ideal. Regularly rotating the plant will ensure all sides receive equal light and promote even growth. Outdoor plants should be placed in a location where they receive dappled sunlight or partial shade."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cordyline fruticosa is mainly about removing any dead or yellowing leaves to encourage healthier growth. This can be done at any time of the year. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut leaves at their base. If the plant becomes leggy, it can be pruned back more dramatically by cutting the stem back to encourage sprouting from the base or along the stem. After pruning, the plant can benefit from fertilization and care as it recovers and produces new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Ti","description":"Cordyline fruticosa is an evergreen flowering plant in the Asparagus family, Asparagaceae, known by a wide variety of common names, including cabbage palm, good luck plant, palm lily, ti plant, Kī, Lā‘ī (Hawaiian), Tī Pore (Māori), Sī (Tongan), Lauti (Samoan), and ʻAutī (Tahitian).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green, Red, Purple"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeast Asia","Pacific Islands","Australia"],"other_name":["Ti"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Cordyline fruticosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15820,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ustilago maydis, commonly known as corn smut, is not a typical plant that requires watering. It is actually a pathogenic fungus that grows on maize (corn) plants. Therefore, it does not require watering as a plant does. Instead, it relies on environmental moisture levels and the conditions of its host for growth. If managing corn smut in an agricultural setting, it is crucial to focus on controlling the moisture conditions around the corn plants, which may involve optimizing irrigation practices to prevent conditions that favor the fungus's proliferation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ustilago maydis itself does not have specific sunlight requirements as it is a fungus, not a photosynthetic plant. It depends on its host, the maize plant, for sustenance. Corn, its host plant, requires full sunlight to grow optimally. To manage corn smut, it is important to ensure that the corn plants receive adequate sunlight, as healthy, robust plants can more effectively withstand fungal infections. Maximizing sunlight exposure by proper spacing and planting orientation is beneficial for minimizing fungal diseases in corn cultivation."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Since Ustilago maydis is a fungal pathogen that affects corn rather than a plant itself, typical pruning isn’t applicable. However, managing infected corn plants involves removing and properly disposing of the smut galls to prevent the spread of spores. Early identification and removal of infected plants or plant parts can minimize the spread. It’s important to handle these galls carefully to avoid dispersing the spores and potentially infecting other plants. Regular inspection of the corn crop and maintaining good sanitation practices are the best strategies to manage this fungus organically."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Corn Smut","description":"Corn smut is a plant disease caused by the pathogenic fungus Ustilago maydis that causes smut on maize and teosinte. The fungus forms galls on all above-ground parts of corn species, and is known in Mexico as the delicacy huitlacoche; which is eaten, usually as a filling, in quesadillas and other tortilla-based foods, and soups.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Corn Smut"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Ustilago maydis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15522,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Dracaena draco, or Dragon Tree, prefers infrequent watering, as it is drought-tolerant. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out completely between waterings, which means watering every 2-3 weeks in typical indoor conditions. Be cautious not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. Reduce watering frequency during the winter months when the plant's growth slows down. Always ensure that the pot has good drainage to prevent water from sitting at the bottom, and consider using a well-draining cactus or succulent soil mix to further promote healthy moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dracaena draco thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can also tolerate some direct light. Ideally, place the plant near a window with filtered light, avoiding extended periods of harsh, direct sunlight to prevent leaf scorch. If insufficient natural light is available, the plant can adapt to lower light conditions, but its growth may slow, and leaf color may not be as vibrant. To emulate its natural habitat, try to keep the plant in a location where it receives gentle morning or late afternoon sun, fostering better growth and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning a Dracaena draco involves cutting back any dead or yellowing leaves to maintain its appearance and ensure healthy growth. It’s best to prune in the spring, before the growing season starts. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make cuts just above a leaf node or where the leaf meets the stem. If the plant becomes too tall or leggy, you can also prune the stem to encourage new branching. Always ensure your tools are sanitized before pruning to prevent the spread of disease, and consider sealing larger cuts with pruning paint if needed."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"dragon-tree","description":"Not to be confused with the related Dracaena cinnabari, the dragon blood tree native to Socotra (an island in the Arabian Sea, part of Yemen).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Orange\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Canary Islands","Cape Verde","Madeira","Azores"],"other_name":["dragon-tree"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Dracaena draco"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14329,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Perilla frutescens prefers moderately moist soil and should be watered regularly to maintain consistent moisture. It is important to avoid waterlogging, as this can cause root rot. Check the top inch of soil; if it feels dry, it's time to water. In hot climates or during prolonged dry periods, you may need to water more frequently, but always ensure good drainage. Mulching can also help retain moisture and regulate the soil temperature around the plant roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Perilla frutescens thrives in full sun to partial shade. It requires at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and flavor development in its leaves. While it can tolerate some shade, too little light can reduce the plant's overall vigor and leaf production. In hot climates, partial shade during the hottest part of the day can protect the plant from stress and leaf scorch. Ensure the planting site receives morning sunlight, which is less intense, to promote robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Perilla frutescens encourages bushier growth and helps maintain a tidy shape. Regularly pinch back the growing tips to encourage branching, especially when the plant is young. If any flowers appear, consider removing them to prolong the growing season of the edible leaves. In late summer or early autumn, cut back the plant to prevent it from going to seed unless you want it to self-seed the following year. Removing dead or yellowing leaves will keep the plant healthy and allow for better air circulation."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"beefsteak plant","description":"Perilla frutescens, commonly called perilla or Korean perilla, is a species of Perilla in the mint family Lamiaceae. It is an annual plant native to Southeast Asia and Indian highlands, and grown in the Korean peninsula, Southern China and India. Known as deulkkae (들깨) in Korean, the plant was introduced into Korea before the Unified Silla era, when it started to be widely cultivated.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","India","Japan","Korea","Southeast Asia"],"other_name":["beefsteak plant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Perilla frutescens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Overwatering can cause root rot, so ensure proper drainage and reduce watering during periods of rainfall. During the growing season, watering once a week should suffice, but adjust based on local climate and soil conditions. If planted in a very shady spot, consider relocating it to a sunnier area to optimize its health and flowering. Plants in partial shade conditions may require less frequent watering compared to those in full sun."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Verbesina virginica is relatively simple and can be done to maintain shape and encourage bushier growth. It is best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove dead or damaged stems and any that are crossing or crowding the plant. This also improves airflow and reduces disease risk. For aesthetics and control, cutting back one-third of the plant's height can help manage size and create a tidier appearance. Regular deadheading of spent flowers also promotes prolific blooming."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"frostweed","description":"Verbesina virginica, the white crownbeard, is a species of flowering plant in the aster family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14727,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Russula virescens, commonly known as the green-cracked brittlegill, is a type of mushroom, so traditional plant watering guidelines do not apply. However, if you are cultivating this mushroom, it's important to maintain a consistently moist environment. Keep the substrate or soil where the mushrooms are growing damp, but not waterlogged, to mimic the natural forest floor conditions where these fungi thrive. Ideally, use a spray bottle to mist the area, ensuring the top layer doesn't dry out completely while avoiding oversaturation, which can lead to mold or other fungal issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Russula virescens prefers dappled sunlight similar to its natural habitat on the forest floor. If you are cultivating these mushrooms indoors or in a controlled setting, aim to provide indirect sunlight or filtered artificial light. Direct, harsh sunlight may dry out the growing substrate and inhibit mushroom development. Instead, emulate the speckled light of a forest canopy, ensuring some natural light but avoiding overexposure. Maintaining a balanced light level encourages healthy growth while supporting the mushroom's natural coloration and structural integrity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to fungi like Russula virescens. Instead of pruning, focus on managing their growing environment since they don't develop branches or leaves like traditional plants. Monitor for any signs of mold or decay around the growing area and remove any infected material to prevent spread. Additionally, these mushrooms should be harvested by gently twisting and pulling them from their base when they are mature to encourage further growth and maintain a healthy growing environment. Ensure not to damage the mycelium, which is crucial for ongoing mushroom production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Green Russula","description":"Russula virescens is a basidiomycete mushroom of the genus Russula, and is commonly known as the green-cracking russula, the quilted green russula, or the green brittlegill. It can be recognized by its distinctive pale green cap that measures up to 15 cm (6 in) in diameter, the surface of which is covered with darker green angular patches. It has crowded white gills, and a firm, white stipe that is up to 8 cm (3 in) tall and 4 cm (1.6 in) thick....","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Green Russula"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Russula virescens"],"soil":[],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15325,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Platanthera huronensis, commonly known as the Huron green orchid, requires moisture-rich conditions similar to those found in its native habitats like wetlands and moist meadows. When cultivating this orchid, it’s important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Be sure to water thoroughly and frequently during the growing season, especially if cultivated in drier climates. Reduce watering during the winter dormancy period but do not allow the substrate to dry out completely. Mimicking its natural environment by using rainwater or distilled water is also beneficial as these orchids can be sensitive to hard water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Platanthera huronensis thrives in partial to full shade, reflecting the conditions of its natural habitat. It is suited to environments where it receives filtered sunlight, such as beneath canopy layers of wetland and woodland areas. In cultivation, providing dappled light or ensuring it doesn’t receive harsh direct sunlight during peak daytime hours is crucial to prevent leaf scorch. This orchid benefits from morning sun and afternoon shade, which replicates the gentle light conditions it prefers. Avoid placing it in full sun; instead, offer protection using shade cloths if necessary to diffuse intense light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Platanthera huronensis is not typically necessary as it is a wild orchid species grown more for its natural form than structured aesthetics. Instead, focus on maintaining plant health by removing any dead or dying leaves and spent flower spikes after the flowering season. This not only keeps the plant looking tidy but also prevents any potential spread of diseases. When removing flower spikes, cut them gently at the base using sterilized scissors to avoid damaging the plant or introducing pathogens. Regularly inspect for pests or any signs of disease and address promptly to maintain health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"green bog orchid","description":"Platanthera huronensis, the Huron green orchid, is a species of orchid native to the United States and Canada. It has a discontinuous range, the eastern range including eastern Canada from eastern Manitoba to Labrador, plus New England and the Great Lakes states. The western range extends along the Rocky Mountains from New Mexico to Alberta, as well as the coastal ranges of Washington, British Columbia and southern Alaska (including the Aleutians).","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["green bog orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Platanthera huronensis"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It’s important not to overwater as this can lead to root rot. Water the plant thoroughly only when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. While it can tolerate some shade, especially in hotter climates, it requires a good amount of sunlight to bloom optimally. Ideally, it should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sun each day. Monitor the plant for signs of too much shade, such as leggy growth and fewer blooms, and adjust its location if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Anemone caroliniana is generally minimal and mostly involves deadheading spent flowers to encourage a longer blooming period and prevent unwanted self-seeding. After the flowering period, cut back any dead or damaged foliage to maintain a tidy appearance. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid disease transmission and ensure a clean cut."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Carolina Anemone","description":"Anemone caroliniana, the Carolina anemone, is a herbaceous plant species in the genus Anemone and family Ranunculaceae. Plants grow (7)10 to 40 cm tall, from short tuber-like rhizomes that are 10–30 mm long. Stem leaves without petioles. It thrives in a well-draining orchid mix to prevent root rot. Water the plant thoroughly once the top inch of the soil begins to dry out, usually about once a week. This plant appreciates higher humidity, so consider misting the leaves or placing the orchid near a humidity tray. Avoid letting water sit on the leaves to prevent mold development. Adjust watering frequency with the seasonal changes, providing more during growing periods and less in dormancy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Disa ferruginea prefers bright, indirect sunlight to thrive. It should be placed in a spot that receives filtered light or in the morning sun, avoiding harsh afternoon rays that can scorch the leaves. If grown indoors, a north or east-facing window is ideal. If natural light is insufficient, a grow light can supplement the plant's needs to ensure it receives adequate lighting for photosynthesis. Monitor the plant for signs of too much or too little light; red leaves can indicate too much sunlight, while pale leaves might suggest insufficient light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Disa ferruginea is minimal but essential to maintain its health and appearance. Remove any dead or yellowing leaves to encourage healthy growth and improve airflow around the plant. After the flowering has finished, remove spent flower stems to redirect the plant's energy towards new growth. Use sterilized scissors to prevent the spread of disease. Be careful not to damage new growth when pruning. Regularly inspecting the plant for any signs of disease or pest infestation is beneficial to catch potential problems early."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Cluster Disa","description":"Disa ferruginea is a stout, reed-like terrestrial 200-450mm tall. Radical leaves linear, developing after flowering;cauline leaves dry, sheathing. Inflorescence dense, 1-40 flowered. Flowers bright red to orange, often with some parts yellow. Median sepal apiculate, galea 8-10 mm deep;spur slender, grading into the galea, 7-20 mm long;lateral sepals projecting away;elliptic to narrowly elliptic, with apiculi up to 4 mm long;petals spear-shaped, 5-7 mm long;lip narrowly egg to spear-shaped, 10-12 mm long.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Cluster Disa"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Disa ferruginea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15920,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Russula xerampelina, more commonly known as the shrimp mushroom, is a mycorrhizal fungus and primarily thrives in moist environments. In its natural habitat, it benefits from consistent humidity and damp leaf litter found in forest floors. When cultivated, ensure the surrounding soil remains uniformly moist but not waterlogged, as excessive water can lead to root rot or fungal issues in the surrounding flora. Water regularly, especially during dry spells, to mimic its native moist conditions, but allow the top layer of soil to dry slightly between waterings to facilitate healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Russula xerampelina thrives in environments with dappled sunlight, as it naturally grows on forest floors under the canopy of trees. When simulating these conditions, provide indirect sunlight or partial shade. Direct sunlight can dry out and damage the delicate fungal tissues, so it's important to replicate its shaded habitat. If grown outdoors, select a spot with filtered sunlight, mimicking the natural filtering provided by trees. For indoor or controlled environments, use diffused lighting to illuminate the area. Balance is key, ensuring the fungus receives enough light to grow healthily without excessive exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Russula xerampelina, being a wild mushroom, doesn’t require pruning. However, during cultivation, it's essential to maintain hygiene in the growing area. Remove any surrounding plant debris and other fungi to prevent competition and potential contamination. If foraging, ensure that any non-target mushrooms are not encroaching on the Russula patches. Keeping the environment clean and free from decaying matter, where pests might inhabit, helps in promoting healthy fungal growth. For cultivated environments, supervising the growth at the base and promptly managing any competing weed-like organisms supports optimal conditions."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Shellfish-scented Russula","description":"Russula xerampelina, also commonly known as the crab brittlegill or the shrimp mushroom, is a basidiomycete mushroom of the brittlegill genus Russula. Two subspecies are recognised. The fruiting bodies appear in coniferous woodlands in autumn in northern Europe and North America. Their caps are coloured various shades of wine-red, purple to green. Mild tasting and edible, it is one of the most highly regarded brittlegills for the table. It is also notable for smelling of shellfish...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","North America"],"other_name":["Shellfish-scented Russula"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Russula xerampelina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14927,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cyclamen hederifolium requires careful watering, especially to avoid over-watering. During the active growing season, typically from fall to late spring, keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Reduce watering significantly during the summer dormant period, ensuring the soil remains mostly dry, as the plant does not require much moisture during this time. Always water around the base of the plant rather than from above to avoid direct contact with the foliage, which can lead to rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cyclamen hederifolium thrives best in partial to full shade, making it an ideal plant for shaded or woodland gardens. It prefers indirect sunlight to protect its delicate leaves and flowers from harsh midday sun. If grown indoors, place the plant in a location with bright, filtered light, such as near an east or north-facing window. Avoid direct sunlight, which can cause scorching of the leaves and reduce flowering. During its dormant period in summer, consider moving the plant to a shaded area to rest."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Cyclamen hederifolium is typically minimal and involves removing spent flowers and yellowing leaves to maintain plant health and aesthetics. This should be done carefully by pinching or cutting the stems at the base. Avoid pulling on the foliage or flowers, as this can damage the tuber. Conduct pruning regularly during the flowering season to encourage more blooms and fresh growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14828,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Solidago uliginosa, commonly known as bog goldenrod, prefers consistently moist soil, making it ideal for wetter areas such as bogs, marshes, or near ponds. It's important to maintain a regular watering schedule, especially during dry periods, to keep the soil from drying out completely. Overwatering is typically not an issue given its preference for moist conditions, but it is crucial to ensure the site has good drainage to prevent root rot. In drier landscapes, consider adding mulch to help retain moisture in the soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solidago uliginosa thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, ensure it receives at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. However, it can tolerate some shade, especially in hotter climates where partial shade can protect it from the most intense afternoon sun. If planting in shaded areas, be mindful that the plant might become leggy or produce fewer flowers. Ensure the planted area has good air circulation to prevent mildew and other fungal diseases common in shadier, damp environments."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Solidago uliginosa in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This helps remove dead or damaged stems, promoting healthy growth and improving air circulation. Cut back the plant to about one-third of its height, trimming above a node or where new shoots are visible. Regular pruning encourages bushier growth and can prevent the plant from becoming too leggy. Additionally, removing spent flower stalks after blooming can prevent unwanted self-seeding and maintain a tidy appearance in your garden."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"bog goldenrod","description":"Solidago uliginosa, or bog goldenrod, is a North American species of flowering plants in the sunflower family. It is found in eastern Canada (from Nunavut to Newfoundland and Manitoba) and the eastern United States (Great Lakes, Northeast, and Appalachian Mountains as far south as northeastern Georgia. There are historical reports of the species growing in Alabama, but these populations appear now to have been extirpated).","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["bog goldenrod"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Solidago uliginosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist","Clay","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15225,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Symphyotrichum sericeum, commonly known as silvery aster, prefers well-drained soil and moderate watering. During dry spells, water deeply but infrequently, allowing the water to reach the roots. During the active growing season, water more frequently to support blooming. Soil moisture should be monitored regularly to ensure it's not too wet or too dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Symphyotrichum sericeum thrives in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, provide at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. In areas with intense south or west midday sun, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from excessive heat. However, too much shade can lead to leggy growth and reduced blooming. It's best to prune in the early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems, cutting them back to ground level. After the flowering season, deadhead spent blooms to promote a tidy appearance and prevent self-seeding if desired. Cutting back stems by half in midsummer can encourage fuller growth and more blooms. Ensure sharp, sterilized tools are used to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"silky aster","description":"Symphyotrichum sericeum is a species of flowering plant in the aster family known by several common names, including western silver aster and silky aster. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15326,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Liparis loeselii, commonly known as the Yellow Widows'-cross, thrives in consistently moist conditions as it naturally grows in wet habitats like bogs and marshes. To care for this orchid, ensure that the soil is kept consistently damp, mimicking its natural environment. However, avoid waterlogging as excessive standing water can lead to root rot. Watering frequency may depend on the climate and season, but as a rule of thumb, maintain a moisture level where the substrate never fully dries out. Additionally, using distilled or rainwater can help prevent mineral buildup, which this plant prefers given its natural rainwater-fed habitats."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Liparis loeselii flourishes under indirect, filtered sunlight. In its natural habitat, it often receives dappled light through tall vegetation, so it's crucial to avoid direct harsh sun which can scorch its leaves. Ideally, place it in an area that receives bright, indirect sunlight for several hours a day, like near an east or north-facing window. During the winter months, when daylight hours are shorter, you might consider supplementing with artificial grow lights to mimic longer daylight exposure. Ensuring appropriate light levels is key to its flowering and overall health, reflecting the mild conditions found in its native environments."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Liparis loeselii is minimal, as it generally maintains a compact form. However, it’s beneficial to remove any spent flowers or dried leaves to promote healthy growth and improve aesthetics. Carefully snip off dead flower spikes near the base once they've finished blooming. Additionally, cut away any discolored or diseased leaves at the base using sterilized scissors to prevent potential spread of disease. Regularly checking for these and keeping the plant clean helps maintain its vigor. Remember to always use clean tools to avoid introducing any infections to this delicate orchid species."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"fen orchid","description":"Liparis loeselii, common names fen orchid, yellow widelip orchid, or bog twayblade, is a species of orchid. It is native to Europe, northern Asia, the eastern United States and eastern Canada. It grows in fens, bogs and dune slacks. It is a yellow flowering plant with glossy yellow-green leaves.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["fen orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":["Snails","Slugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Liparis loeselii"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
