{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14529,"attracts":["Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Andropogon gerardi, commonly known as big bluestem, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering once established. In its early growth stages, regular watering is beneficial to help establish a strong root system. Once mature, it typically thrives on natural rainfall and should only be watered during prolonged dry spells. Overwatering can be detrimental, leading to root rot or other moisture-related issues. It's essential to ensure that the soil has good drainage to prevent waterlogging. Adjust watering practices based on climate, with reduced frequency in wetter regions or seasons."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Andropogon gerardi thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day to maintain its robust growth and vibrant foliage. While it can tolerate partial shade, particularly in hotter climates, insufficient sunlight may cause the plant to grow lanky or inhibit its flowering capability. In regions with intense summer heat, providing some afternoon shade can help protect it from stress. Ensuring it receives ample sunlight is crucial for achieving the distinctive tall, upright form and the striking blue-green color for which it is known."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Andropogon gerardi is generally minimal and mostly focused on improving aesthetics and promoting healthy growth. In late winter or early spring, you can cut back the old stems to a few inches above the ground to make way for new growth. This also helps in removing dead or damaged foliage, which can encourage pest issues if left unattended. During the growing season, pruning is rarely necessary unless the plant becomes too unruly or encroaches on other areas. Regularly removing any dead or diseased leaves can also keep the plant looking tidy and healthy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"big bluestem","description":"Andropogon gerardi, known commonly as big bluestem, turkeyfoot, tall bluestem, and bluejoint, is a tall grass (family Poaceae) native to much of the Great Plains and prairie regions of central North America and grasslands, savannas and woodlands throughout eastern North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["big bluestem"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Andropogon gerardi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14429,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus phellos, commonly known as the willow oak, generally requires moderate watering. Young trees should be watered regularly to help establish their root systems. Mature trees are quite drought-tolerant and do not need frequent watering. During dry spells, it’s beneficial to water deeply but infrequently to prevent the soil from drying out completely. Ensure good drainage to avoid waterlogged soil, as this can lead to root rot. Mulching around the base of the tree can help retain soil moisture and protect the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Willow oak thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. It can tolerate partial shade but may experience slower growth and a less robust crown. In optimal conditions, full sun exposure supports vigorous growth, robust foliage, and successful acorn production. When planting, consider a location with unobstructed sunlight to ensure the tree receives ample light. While young saplings can handle some shade, prolonged lack of sunlight can lead to weaker branches and sparse foliage, diminishing the tree's lush aesthetic and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Quercus phellos should primarily be done in the winter months while the tree is dormant. Focus on removing any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to maintain tree health. Additionally, thin out crowded branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. Be sure to make clean cuts just outside the branch collar, being careful not to damage the main trunk or branch. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the tree or lead to excessive sap loss. Minimal pruning is recommended to maintain the tree's natural shape and strong structure."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"willow oak","description":"Quercus phellos, the willow oak, is a North American species of a deciduous tree in the red oak group of oaks. It is native to the eastern and central United States from Long Island Sound south to northern Florida, and west to southernmost Illinois, Missouri, Oklahoma, and eastern Texas. It is most commonly found growing on lowland floodplains, often along streams, but rarely also in uplands with poor drainage, up to 400 meters (1,300 ft) altitude.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeastern United States"],"other_name":["willow oak"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf miners","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Quercus phellos"],"soil":["Acidic","Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During extended dry periods, providing deep watering every few weeks will help maintain the tree’s health and vigor, but be sure the soil has good drainage to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus ellipsoidalis thrives in full sunlight, ideally receiving at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. The primary goal is to remove dead, diseased, or damaged branches, which improves airflow and tree vigor. When pruning, aim to maintain the tree's natural shape and balance. It's also wise to remove any crossed or rubbing branches and promote a strong central leader. Avoid excessive pruning, as this can stress the tree. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14134,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Conocybe apala, commonly known as the white dunce cap, is a delicate, ephemeral mushroom often found in lawns after rain. This mushroom does not require watering as it is not a cultivated plant. Instead, it grows naturally in moist environments, particularly after rainfall. If you are interested in observing them, ensure your lawn is adequately watered but not overly saturated. They will emerge naturally in damp, shaded areas where moisture levels are maintained through natural rain or light, consistent watering if needed for the surrounding vegetation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Conocybe apala, a type of wild mushroom, prefers shaded or semi-shaded areas and does not thrive in direct, intense sunlight. These fungi typically appear in lawns and grassy areas that provide some shelter from direct sun, flourishing under partial shade conditions created by trees or buildings. They tend to grow after rain, indicating their preference for moist, shaded environments. To observe these mushrooms, maintaining an area that has dappled sunlight or is predominantly shaded will create a conducive environment for their natural growth cycle."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Conocybe apala since it is not a typical plant but a wild mushroom. These fungi are not managed like garden plants or shrubs; they grow naturally and require no trimming or maintenance. They appear and disappear quickly, often within a single day, as part of their natural life cycle. For those interested in managing their presence in a lawn or garden, regular mowing and lawn care might help control their numbers, but pruning as understood for plants is unnecessary."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"milky conecap","description":"Conocybe apala is a basidiomycete fungus and a member of Conocybe. It is a fairly common fungus, both in North America and Europe, found growing among short green grass. Water young plants weekly in the absence of rain. Once established, crepe myrtles are fairly drought-tolerant but benefit from occasional deep watering during prolonged dry spells. Be sure to provide sufficient water during bloom time to encourage healthy flower production. Avoid overwatering, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. It's essential to water at the base and keep the foliage dry to prevent fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lagerstroemia indica thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. Planting in a sunny location ensures vibrant blooms and reduces the risk of powdery mildew, a common affliction in shaded areas. While it can tolerate partial shade, this can result in diminished flowering and more leggy growth. Ensure other garden features or larger plants do not cast prolonged shadows over your crepe myrtle to facilitate the best possible flowering and plant health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lagerstroemia indica is crucial to maintain its shape and promote healthy blooming. Perform substantial pruning during late winter or early spring when the plant is dormant. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to encourage an open canopy and good air circulation. Cut back to the main stem or trunk to avoid knobby growths. Avoid topping, which can lead to weak new growth and reduced flowering. Maintain a natural or well-structured shape to enhance both the aesthetic appeal and health of the crepe myrtle."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Crape-myrtle","description":"Lagerstroemia indica (crape myrtle, crepe myrtle, crepeflower) is a species in the genus Lagerstroemia in the family Lythraceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Korea","Japan"],"other_name":["Crape-myrtle"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Powdery mildew","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Lagerstroemia indica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Regular pruning during the growth phase encourages vigorous growth and a tidy appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Chinese yam","description":"Chinese yam (Dioscorea polystachya), also called cinnamon-vine, is a species of flowering plant in the yam family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15724,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Persicaria virginiana, commonly known as jumpseed, prefers consistently moist soil. However, it can tolerate periods of dryness once established. To care for this plant, water it deeply whenever the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Over-watering should be avoided to prevent root rot, a common issue in heavy or poorly-draining soils. In the growing season, especially during periods of drought or excessive heat, increase watering frequency to ensure that the plant remains hydrated. Using mulch can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Persicaria virginiana thrives in partial to full shade environments but can tolerate some sunlight. For optimal growth, it's best to situate this plant in an area where it receives dappled light or morning sun followed by afternoon shade. Avoid placing it in direct, intense afternoon sunlight as the leaves can scorch and lose their vibrant color. If placed in too much shade, while Persicaria virginiana can survive, it may become leggy or fail to bloom as prolifically. Adapting to the available lighting conditions, this plant is quite versatile within suitable ranges."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Persicaria virginiana is generally minimal, focused on maintaining shape and encouraging healthy growth. In early spring, remove any dead or damaged stems to allow new growth to flourish. As the plant produces flowers, you can deadhead spent blooms to promote a tidier appearance and potentially extend the blooming period. In late fall, cutting back the plant to a few inches above ground level can help it to come back more robustly the following year and reduce the risk of pests and diseases lingering over the winter months."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"American jumpseed","description":"Persicaria virginiana, also called jumpseed, Virginia knotweed or woodland knotweed is a North American species of smartweed within the buckwheat family. It is unusual as a shade-tolerant member of a mostly sun-loving genus. During hotter summer months, increased watering may be necessary, while in the cooler months, water sparingly. It is ideal to allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between watering sessions, maintaining a balance to ensure the plant gets sufficient moisture without being oversaturated."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ruellia caroliniensis thrives in a variety of sunlight conditions but prefers full sun to partial shade. It can tolerate full sun for several hours, which will encourage prolific blooming. However, the plant also adapts to partial shade, though flowering may be less robust in such conditions. Ideally, aim to provide this plant with at least four to six hours of sunlight each day. In areas with very harsh afternoon sun, some dappled shade during the hottest part of the day can prevent the foliage from scorching and keep the plant healthier overall."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ruellia caroliniensis can help maintain its shape and encourage fuller growth. The best time to prune is in early spring before the new growth starts. Begin by removing any dead or damaged stems and spent flowers to promote new blooms. Cutting back the plant by about one-third can encourage bushier foliage. During the growing season, regular deadheading can help maintain its appearance and increase the plant's blooming period. Always use clean, sharp tools to avoid damaging the plant and to minimize the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Carolina ruellia","description":"Ruellia caroliniensis, the Carolina wild petunia, is a wild petunia with blue or violet flowers that appear in the spring, summer, and autumn. Afterward, mature trees generally require less frequent watering, usually only during prolonged dry spells. This allows you to shape the tree, remove dead or diseased branches, and improve its structure. When pruning, focus on eliminating crossing branches and those that rub against each other to prevent future damage. Keep the tree's natural shape in mind while trimming, and avoid cutting too close to the trunk to prevent bark injury. Regular maintenance pruning once every few years should suffice to keep the Turkey oak healthy and well-structured."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Turkey Oak","description":"Quercus cerris, the Turkey oak or Austrian oak, is an oak native to south-eastern Europe and Asia Minor. Mulching can also help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lobelia puberula thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the plant from becoming scorched. Ensuring adequate sunlight not only promotes prolific blooming but also helps maintain a compact, sturdy structure. Adjusting the sun exposure based on specific climate and seasonal changes can be beneficial for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lobelia puberula is primarily done to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. After the blooming period, you can prune back the plant by cutting spent flowers and leggy stems. This encourages a second wave of blooms and helps prevent the plant from becoming too unruly. In late fall, pruning down to the basal foliage can help it prepare for winter dormancy. Always use clean, sharp tools to make cuts, which minimizes stress and the risk of disease. Regular deadheading throughout the growing season keeps the plant tidy and encourages continuous blooming."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"downy lobelia","description":"Lobelia puberula, or downy lobelia, is a perennial herbaceous wildflower in the Bellflower family (Campanulaceae) native to eastern and south central United States. Watering once a week should suffice, using enough water to keep the soil evenly moist without flooding. During hotter, dryer periods, check the soil more frequently to ensure it does not dry out completely, as this can stress the plant. Adjust its position seasonally to maintain balanced light exposure throughout the year."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Platanthera aquilonis involves minimal interference to allow the plant to grow naturally. The best approach is to remove dead or diseased foliage to prevent any potential spread of disease. This should be done carefully to avoid damaging healthy parts of the plant. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15424,"attracts":["Bees","Birds","Moths"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Protea cynaroides requires careful watering to prevent root rot. During its growing season in spring and summer, water the plant moderately once the top couple of inches of soil feel dry. The soil should be well-draining, and it's crucial to avoid waterlogging. In the fall and winter months, reduce watering frequencies, allowing the plant to enter a more natural dormancy phase. It's preferable to use rainwater or distilled water as proteas are sensitive to high mineral content in water, especially phosphorus, which can be detrimental to their health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Protea cynaroides thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. This plant is native to South Africa's sunny regions, and thus, it is well adapted to bright light conditions. Ensure it receives adequate light to promote healthy growth and abundant flowering. In cooler climates, a south-facing window or a sunroom can be suitable locations if grown indoors. Be cautious of placing the plant in excessively shady areas, as insufficient sunlight can lead to poor flowering and weaker stems."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Protea cynaroides is essential to encourage new growth and maintain a manageable size. Best time to prune is late winter or early spring when the threat of frost has passed. Cut back spent flowers to a point just above a leaf node or pair of leaves to stimulate branching and flower production. It's important to remove any dead or diseased stems to improve airflow and light penetration. While cutting, always use sterilized pruning shears to minimize disease risk. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant and reduce flowering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"King Protea","description":"Protea cynaroides, the king protea, is a flowering plant. It is a distinctive member of Protea, having the largest flower head in the genus. The species is also known as giant protea, honeypot or king sugar bush. It is widely distributed in the southwestern and southern parts of South Africa in the fynbos region.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["King Protea"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Protea cynaroides"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14431,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Zanthoxylum clava-herculis, commonly known as the Hercules' Club, is moderately drought-tolerant once established. Water young plants regularly to help them develop a strong root system. Aim to keep the soil slightly moist, allowing the top inch to dry out between waterings. Once the tree is mature, it can tolerate longer dry periods, but will benefit from occasional deep watering during extended dry spells to promote healthy growth and fruiting. Ensure good drainage to prevent root rot, particularly if planted in heavy clay soils."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Zanthoxylum clava-herculis thrives in full sun to partial shade. It performs best in locations where it receives at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. While the plant can tolerate some shade, providing ample sunlight ensures optimal growth and the production of its distinctive spine-covered branches and aromatic foliage. In regions with very hot climates, a little afternoon shade may help prevent leaf scorch and reduce water stress, although it generally adapts well to its environment."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Zanthoxylum clava-herculis should be done in late winter to early spring before new growth emerges. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain the health of the tree. Thin out dense branches to improve air circulation and light penetration, which aids in reducing disease pressure and encourages balanced growth. Be cautious of the thorny branches when pruning this plant. Shaping is typically not necessary beyond maintaining a clear trunk for ease of maintenance and access."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hercules' club","description":"Zanthoxylum clava-herculis (Hercules' club, Hercules-club, pepperwood, or southern prickly ash) is a spiny tree or shrub native to the southeastern United States. It grows to 10–17 m tall and has distinctive spined thick, corky lumps 2–3 cm long on the bark. The leaves are glabrous and leathery, pinnately compound, 20–30 cm long with 7-19 leaflets, each leaflet 4–5 cm long. The flowers are dioecious, in panicles up to 20 cm long, each flower small, 6–8 mm diameter, with 3-5 white petals....","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Hercules' club"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Zanthoxylum clava-herculis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15923,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mauritia flexuosa, commonly known as the Moriche palm, thrives in moist environments and requires a lot of water for optimal growth. Consider using a saucer or tray filled with water to maintain humidity if growing indoors."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mauritia flexuosa prefers full sunlight and grows best in regions with abundant natural light. If growing indoors or in a location with limited natural light, consider supplementing with grow lights to meet its high light requirements. Ideally, this plant should receive six to eight hours of bright, direct sunlight daily for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mauritia flexuosa involves removing dead or damaged fronds to encourage healthy growth and maintain the plant's appearance. The species doesn’t typically require extensive pruning, but regular maintenance is beneficial. Use clean, sharp shears and cut the fronds near the trunk, taking care not to damage the palm’s crown. Avoid removing green fronds as they are crucial for the plant's photosynthesis and overall health. Pruning may also help control the size of the plant if necessary, especially in cultivated environments where space can be limited."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"moriche palm","description":"Mauritia flexuosa, known as the moriche palm, ité palm, ita, buriti, muriti, canangucho (Colombia), or aguaje (Peru), is a palm tree. It has been reported from Trinidad, Colombia, Venezuela, Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana, Brazil, Ecuador, Peru, and Bolivia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["moriche palm"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Mauritia flexuosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14634,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Acer ginnala, or Amur maple, prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil conditions. Water the tree regularly, especially during dry periods, to maintain soil moisture. However, ensure that the soil does not become waterlogged, as this can lead to root rot. During the first few years after planting, regular watering is crucial to help the tree establish a strong root system. Once established, the tree is more tolerant of drought, though occasional watering during extended dry spells will promote healthier growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Amur maple thrives in full sun to partial shade, preferring at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and vibrant fall coloration. While it can tolerate some shade, less sunlight may result in less intense autumn colors. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. When planting, choose a location that offers the right balance of sunlight for your area's climate to ensure healthy growth and the best display of the tree's decorative features."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is best done in late winter to early spring before the tree begins its active growth. Focus on removing any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to maintain the tree's health and structure. Light pruning to shape the tree can also be performed during this period. It's also important to trim any crossing branches to prevent them from rubbing against each other, which can cause wounds. Additionally, remove any suckers or water sprouts that may develop at the base or along the trunk. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14635,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pseudoscleropodium purum, commonly known as Neat Feather Moss, typically thrives in humid environments. When cultivating this moss indoors or in gardens, it's important to maintain consistent moisture without waterlogging its substrate. Water the moss regularly, using a spray bottle to mist it gently, ensuring that the moisture penetrates its structure evenly. To prevent desiccation, particularly in dryer climates or indoor settings, employ the use of a humidity tray or maintain ambient humidity levels. Avoid using hard or chlorinated water, opting for rainwater or distilled water to prevent leaf damage and to maintain optimal moss health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pseudoscleropodium purum prefers a shaded location with dappled sunlight, mimicking its natural understory habitat. When grown indoors, place this moss in a spot that receives indirect light, as direct sunlight can cause it to dry out and become stressed. If placed outdoors, ensure it's in a spot protected from harsh sun exposure, such as under trees or larger shrubs. However, too much shade might hinder growth, so finding a balance is key. Consider using artificial lighting if natural light is insufficient, maintaining a low to medium intensity to mimic the natural conditions of a forest floor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pseudoscleropodium purum involves minimal effort, as it is a low-maintenance moss. However, it's essential to occasionally remove any dead or discolored sections, which can be done using small scissors or by gently picking them out by hand. This practice helps maintain the moss's health by preventing the spread of decay and ensuring better light penetration to the lower layers. Regular pruning also encourages denser growth and a more aesthetically pleasing appearance. In garden settings, monitor for any overgrowth that could encroach upon other plants and trim as needed to maintain boundaries."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Neat Feather-moss","description":"Pseudoscleropodium purum, or neat feather-moss, is a species of moss and the sole representative of the genus Pseudoscleropodium.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Neat Feather-moss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pseudoscleropodium purum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During its first growing season, it's important to water regularly to help the plant develop a strong root system. Ensure the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. Once matured, water the plant deeply once a week, especially during dry spells or prolonged periods of heat, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Be careful not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Syringa reticulata thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and blooming. Although it can tolerate partial shade, reduced sunlight might result in fewer flowers and less vigorous growth. Plant this lilac in a location that receives ample sunlight to promote abundant blooms. Take care to provide this plant with morning sunlight if the area is particularly hot during summer afternoons, as this can help prevent scorching of leaves."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune your Syringa reticulata in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove dead, damaged, or diseased wood to maintain plant health. Cut back any crossing branches to enhance air circulation and light penetration in the tree's canopy. Additionally, if you want to encourage a tree form, prune lower branches and thin out the crown a bit to ensure the structure you desire. Since this tree flowers on old wood, avoid heavy pruning after buds have formed to prevent loss of blooms for the season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Japanese Tree Lilac","description":"Syringa reticulata (Japanese tree lilac; Chinese: 暴马丁香 bao ma ding xiang; error: {{lang-xx}}: text has italic markup (help)) is a species of Lilac, native to eastern Asia: in northern Japan (mainly Hokkaidō), northern China (Gansu, Hebei, Heilongjiang, Henan, Jilin, Liaoning, Nei Mongol, Ningxia, Shaanxi, Shanxi, Sichuan), Korea, and far southeastern Russia (Primorye).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Japan","Korea"],"other_name":["Japanese Tree Lilac"],"pest_susceptibility":["Lilac borer","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Syringa reticulata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's adaptable to different light conditions, but its growth may become sparse in too much shade, where it might not receive enough energy from sunlight to maintain a dense appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Agrostis hyemalis is a straightforward process.
